conclusion: Shadow position depends on the relative positions of the object and light source, and shadow size depends on the distance between the object and light source.
In the initial configuration, shadows A, B, C, and D are cast on the ground, with their position and size determined by the height and angle of the light source relative to each object.
When the light source moves downward, the height decreases, and the angle of incidence becomes steeper, meaning the light rays hit the objects more directly from above.
With the light source moving downward, shadows will shift slightly toward the objects themselves due to the light rays becoming more vertical, reducing lateral displacement.
As the light source moves closer to the objects, shadows will become larger due to the light rays spreading out more as they pass around the objects.
When the light source moves downward, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to their respective objects and become larger.
